Constructor Detail

HandlerContainer

public HandlerContainer()
Creates a handler container class with automatic binding.

See Also:
HandlerContainer( boolean autoBind )

HandlerContainer

public HandlerContainer(boolean autoBind)
Creates a handler container class with or without automatic binding. If automatic binding is requested, the bind() method will be called automatically after the class is instantiated through Guice/GIN dependency injection mechanism. Otherwise, the user is responsible for calling bind().

Parameters:
autoBind - True to request automatic binding, false otherwise.
Method Detail

bind

public final void bind()
Call this method after the object is constructed in order to bind all its handlers.

When automatic binding is used (see HandlerContainer( boolean autoBind )), this will be called immediately after the object is constructed through Guice/GIN dependency injection mechanism. This is done so that any singleton are correctly initialised. For this reason you should never call bind() directly from the constructor.

If you are not using automatic binding, or if you later call unbind() on this object, you will have to call bind() again manually to make sure its handlers are bound.

Multiple call to bind will not fail, the class will be bound once.

unbind

public final void unbind()
Called after the object has been finished with for the moment.

onBind

public void onBind()
Important : Make sure you call your parent class onBind().

This method is called when binding the object. Any event handlers should be initialised here rather than in the constructor. Other costly initialisation should be done here too, in order to speed-up construction.

Handlers registered by calling (HandlerRegistration) will be removed automatically. Any other initialisation that takes place here (or as a side-effect of what is done here) should be taken down in unbind().

This method will never be invoked more then once, or if it is, the second time will necessarily be preceded by an invocation of unbind().

onUnbind

public void onUnbind()
Important : Make sure you call your parent class onUnbind().

This method is called when unbinding the object. Any handler registrations recorded with (HandlerRegistration) will have already been removed at this point. You should take down any other initialisation that took place in unbind()

This method will never be invoked more then once, or if it is, the second time will necessarily be preceded by an invocation of bind().
